awd_titl_txt: Contextual sensitivity and early number concept development: Pathways to mathematics learning difficulties and disabilities among children with or without Turner syndrome
awd_abstract_narration:
Individuals with mathematics learning disabilities are at risk for lifelong underachievement in mathematics, which can affect broader education and career related outcomes.  The early development of mathematics learning disabilities is poorly understood. The learning of number words is important but often difficult for young children and could be critically important.  The expression "one bin of apples" conveys an image of many more apples than the expression "two apples."  Yet, "one" is smaller than "two."  For young children, particularly girls with Turner Syndrome and children at a high risk for math learning disabilities, the context surrounding number words may be missed, leading to confusion in both early math and higher order mathematics.  In this research, the investigators will explore the development of "contextual sensitivity" toward number words. By examining both the way in which these contexts are understood as well as the cognitive skills needed to improve this understanding, the project will help clarify the developmental trajectory of early math learning disabilities.  

The investigators will explore whether differences in language development can explain or predict math learning disabilities among young children, ages 4-7, who either have Turner Syndrome or are at high risk for math learning disabilities.  The team will measure the construct of "contextual sensitivity" as it relates to the interpretation of number words. The team will investigate how contextual sensitivity and executive function impact number word interpretations. The investigators will assess students with Turner Syndrome as well as students from low income homes.  Both of these populations share a high risk for math disabilities although they differ in their skills in the areas of executive function and vocabulary.  The study will be able to provide insights on the interrelationship between different cognitive domains and math disabilities.

This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring: STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development. The program supports the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to understand, build theory to explain, and suggest intervention and innovations to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning and participation.

por.por_cntn:
Individuals rely on number skills throughout their lives, whether at school, work, or play; and yet 7 to 15% of individuals have significant number processing difficulties. Many more individuals do not achieve proficiency in school mathematics: According to the 2019 National Assessment of Educational Progress report, partial math proficiency ("basic knowledge") is reached by 81% of U.S. fourth graders, 69% of U.S. eighth graders, and 60% of U.S. 12th graders, with full proficiency reached by even fewer children (41%, 34%, and 24%, respectively).  One way to address these math learning challenges is by establishing a solid foundation for mathematical thinking and learning before or soon after school entry.

In early childhood, knowledge about what numbers are and how numbers relate to one another is foundational for learning school mathematics. Our prior work has shown that children's (a) understanding that numbers represent specific quantities (cardinal values), their (b) ability to mentally combine (add) small sets (such as 1 and 3 makes 4) and their (c) ability to rapidly compare quantities (such as knowing 4 is more than 2) are predictive of whether children are likely to show steady gains in mathematics achievement or are likely to consistently lag behind their peers in math achievement throughout their school years. This association between early number knowledge and later math achievement trajectories has lifelong implications because children who experience consistent difficulties with school math are more likely to lack basic mathematical skills that support quality of life in terms of employment success, daily living skills (budgeting, scheduling), and success with sports and hobbies.

Our earlier work demonstrated associations between underdeveloped number skills at kindergarten and persistent misconceptions about numbers and number systems, including difficulties with fractions and computational skills. In this project, we considered the obstacles to young children's number concept development and focused on the contexts in which numbers appear.

We proposed that children vary in terms of their tendency to evaluate numbers in contexts. We considered verbal context that may promote ambiguity in meanings of number words. For example, when comparing "Three cookies" and "two plates of cookies," 3 cookies is less than 2 plates of cookies if the 2 plates have 4 or more cookies altogether. In our study, we found that many preschool and kindergarten children equated the larger number word with the larger set (reporting that 3 cookies was more than 2 plates of cookies); and that some children persisted with this reasoning even when illustrations clearly showed that, for example, the 2 plates of cookies had a total of 4 cookies. Not all children made such "literal" number comparisons, but their tendency to do so was related to their math scores on a standardized test of early mathematics ability and skill. Although children in Grade 2 were less likely to make these sorts of errors compared to children in preschool and kindergarten, some children at all four grade levels did so. This finding reveals developmental and individual differences in how young children think about and apply meanings to number words.

We also found effects of physical context on whether children even notice or attend to numerical features in play materials, which may extend to instructional materials. We designed a matching task in which children chose which of four illustrations best matched a target illustration. We observed whether children even noticed that one illustration matched the target on quantity (the number of items in the set). On all trials, one picture (a "foil") did not match the target at all. We manipulated whether the two remaining pictures matched the target on a very noticeable feature (color or shape) or a more subtle feature (pattern, such as dotted or striped items; or positional orientation of the items). On all trials, PreK to Grade 2 children were first asked to identify the "best match" and were then asked to identify all other matches from the three remaining choices. Children rarely selected a picture that matched the target on quantity, but they were even less likely to notice the number-based match if the other illustrations matched the target on color or shape; and were more likely to notice the number-based match when alternative illustrations matched the target on pattern or positional orientation. In other words, we made number more noticeable to children by manipulating the competing features. We saw large differences across individuals in how often children noticed the number-based match options and how strongly individuals were influenced by this manipulation of features.

Our study contributes to understanding individual differences in numerical processing and sensitivity to contextual influences on numerical processing. This work has implications for assessment of young children's early number concepts, designing materials to support early mathematical thinking and learning (such as counting books and instructional games), and the verbal context accompanying math instructional materials (such as instructional language).
